metadata.case_name: Legatees under 1906 Will v. Kesavan Kaimal and Transferees

facts.text: Will executed on 28th Makaram 1081 M.E. (10th February 1906) jointly by Kunhan Kaimal (son of Karayamvattath Katbayakkal Kunhu Kutti Amma), Kesavan Kaimal (son of Theyi Amma), and Theyi Amma (daughter of Nani Amma) of Etathiruthi amsom and Etamuttan desom in Ponnani Taluk.

Full text of the will: Settled that all movable and immovable properties acquired jointly and separately till now, in future, devolved or obtained shall be held by executants in possession and control till death; after death, to children of Kalliani Amma (Kali, Kunhu Kutty), Thona Amma (Parukutty, Kunhunni, Kochu Govindan, Ramar), deceased Narayani Amma (Kunhunniri, Kuttiparu, Lakshmikutty) and their descendants in equal shares hereditarily. No claim before death. Transferees bound only by remaining properties. No other persons to claim after death.
Each executant possessed self-acquisitions; some jointly acquired as tenants-in-common, not joint tenants.
Theyi Amma died first (exact date not material).
Kunhan Kaimal died sometime in 1930.
Kesavan Kaimal claimed survivorship to all properties under will, including Kunhan Kaimal's.
Kesavan Kaimal conveyed seven items (three belonging to Kunhan Kaimal) to Sankarankutti Kaimal on October 14, 1938.
Kesavan Kaimal conveyed another three items (belonging to Kunhan Kaimal) to Kalyani and Vijayan on October 16, 1944.
Mortgage for Rs. 100 created over three properties (Kunhan Kaimal's) on February 3, 1901.

O.S. No. 131 of 1945 filed by legatees under 1906 will in District Munsif, Chowghat, for possession of three items (Kunhan Kaimal's) after redeeming mortgage. Plaintiffs: legatees. Defendants 1-3: mortgagees; D6: Kesavan Kaimal; D4-5: transferees under 1944 deed.
In O.S. 131/1945, defendants 4-6 contested, pleaded survivorship to Kesavan Kaimal on Kunhan's death.
District Munsif decreed O.S. 131/1945 for plaintiffs (legatees).
Appeals: A.S. 179/1946 (D4-5), A.S. 180/1946 (D6 Kesavan) in Subordinate Judge Calicut/Ottapalam; dismissed, agreed with Munsif.

O.S. No. 158 of 1945 filed by Sankarankutti Kaimal (transferee under 1938 deed) in District Munsif Chowghat for possession/ejectment of three items (one Kunhan absolute, two co-owned). Alleged oral lease to D1 Kali Amma (LRs D2-3), arrears, title dispute. D4: Kesavan Kaimal.
In O.S. 158/1945, defendants (legatees, same as plaintiffs in 131) pleaded title under will to Kunhan's properties, denied oral lease, limitation bar. District Munsif dismissed suit.
Appeal A.S. 336/1946 in Subordinate Judge Ottapalam dismissed.
S.A. 2256/1947 (by Kesavan D6) and S.A. 2545/1948 (by Sankarankutti) in Madras High Court before Raghava Rao J.
Madras HC held will created joint ownership in three testators; interests survived to Kesavan on deaths of Theyi and Kunhan. Allowed both S.As: dismissed O.S. 131/1945, decreed O.S. 158/1945.
Present appeals to Supreme Court on certificate under Art. 136.
Partition deed dated May 16, 1915, and mortgage deed dated March 4, 1926, to which Kesavan was party, treated properties as separate.

E.A. 320/1938 in S.C. 480/1933: Kunhunni Kaimal decree vs Kesavan, sold tarwad properties, tarwad applied for redelivery under O.21 r.100, dismissed. Munsif noted Kesavan had power under will. Not res judicata.

legal_issues.text: Whether one Kesavan Kaimal who was one of three executants of a will dated February 10, 1906, became entitled under that will to the properties, which are the subject-matter of these appeals.
Whether under the will all the three testators became joint owners of all the properties on which it operated.

petitioner_arguments.text: Will is testamentary disposition by each testator of their own properties, operating on death of each; legatees entitled on Kunhan Kaimal's death in 1930. No joint ownership or survivorship. Subsequent conduct shows separate ownership (partition 1915, mortgage 1926).

respondent_arguments.text: Will construed as transfer by testators of individual properties to themselves as joint tenants; survivorship to Kesavan on deaths of others. Subsequent conduct (Kesavan dealing with properties, tarwad not disputing in 1938 EA, Munsif observation) shows parties understood as joint estate. Theyi Amma unlikely to disinherit son Kesavan.

court_reasoning.text: Will executed jointly because same legatees intended, but each bequeathed own properties; operates as will on death of each testator.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Each testator entitled to will own properties; joint execution for convenience.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents' construction is inter vivos transfer to joint tenancy, but document is unstamped will, not disposition in praesenti; future properties cannot be subject of present transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No words divesting individual ownership; clause emphasizes testators' rights till death.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 3 allows alienation jointly or severally till death, inconsistent with joint tenancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Joint property cannot be alienated singly.

court_reasoning.text: Will refers to 'properties jointly acquired' as tenants-in-common, not joint properties.
Subsequent conduct inadmissible as language clear and unambiguous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partition/mortgage deeds show separate understanding, but irrelevant anyway.

court_reasoning.text: Joint will valid: operates as separate wills for each testator's property. Not mutual will as legatees distinct from testators.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Halsbury, Jarman, Duddell v Roundway cited.

holdings.text: Will dated February 10, 1906, is testamentary disposition by three testators of their properties, operating on death of each; joint will but in effect three wills combined. No inter vivos transfer or joint tenancy created.
On Kunhan Kaimal's death in 1930, his properties vested in legatees; Kesavan Kaimal and transferees have no claim.

precedents_cited.relevance: Joint will operates on death of each testator as disposition of their own property.

statutes_cited.name: Stamp Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Will unstamped; if inter vivos, would require stamp.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Application for redelivery in execution dismissed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, held the 1906 document is a will vesting properties of each testator in legatees on their death, reversed Madras High Court judgment, restored decrees of lower courts: decreed O.S. 131/1945 for legatees' possession after redemption, dismissed O.S. 158/1945 ejectment suit.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of lower court decrees in favor of legatees.

key_quotes.text: The sole point for determination in these appeals is whether under the will all the three testators became joint owners of all the properties on which it operated.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We have come to the conclusion that that is not the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is nevertheless, a will by which each testator bequeathed properties belonging to him or to her, and therefore on the death of each testator, the legatees mentioned in the will would be entitled to the properties of the testator, who dies.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: A joint will, though unusual, is not unknown to law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms validity of joint wills as separate dispositions.
